I haven't been struck by lightning.  I did have the experience of contacting a live spark plug.  I was reaching behind me to shut the go-cart engine down, but instead of hitting the lever, I hit the spark plug instead.  My arm went flying over my head, and came down hard on the steering wheel of the go-cart.  That was a bit painful, though the shock hurt less than the impact with the steering wheel.  I had a bruise on my wrist for a while after that.  There was no mark on my finger where I contacted the spark plug. Just my personal encounter with high voltage.

You can't have high voltage and low current. You can have a high static voltage, but as soon as the discharge starts to happen the voltage drops, due to mainly a high internal resistance (the charges can't get to the surface and jump the gap fast enough). So you have a low (or lower, it still needs to be fairly high to discharge at all) voltage low current discharge that happens relatively slowly. Your demo actually shows this quite well, the discharge is much faster (higher current) when it is metal to metal than when you put a piece of meat in between, which has a much higher resistance.
There is also a very limited amount of total charge released, so the amount of energy actually being transferred is very low.

That is wrong. Electrostatic discharge has high voltage AND high current, but low energy in Joules. Remember what Joule is? Wat * Second is one Joule. So 200 kV may has high PEAK current, but overall small effect due to low CAPACITY of the charged object. On such small object you charged, there is just few millijoules of energy stored. That will not kill anyone, just small tingling in fingers...

When I did Electricity and Magnetism course, I learned that a steady current of 10-20 mA can cause involuntary muscle contractions. When the affected person cannot release the source of current, I call this "Joe Cocker experience".

"You heart is a muscle too" The heart is more susceptible because it runs on electrical impulses. So when it is hit with any substantial amount of electricity will change the rhythm which can be harmful. A defibrillator uses electrical impulses to try to fix your heart beat rhythm.

4:20 does this analogy work
voltage is like a pipe, either very fat or very thin (both the same length)
current is like, well the water current
you can have a very fat pipe but only half the pipe, fatness wise, is getting current. High voltage low current.
The fat high voltage pipe has more potential
Ok now we have the same pipe but higher current, the pipe is completely filled. The voltage/pipe is completely the same but the current/water current/how fast the other end of the pipe is getting water is higher
Ok now we have a thinner pipe, low voltage. We set the current/water pressure higher, so a high voltage pipe sends high current to the low voltage pipe, But the low voltage pipe cant take the high current so you only get a small current

Does this analogy work?

Also if the send a high current to a low voltage pipe, you'll probably get a leak.
How does this work with actual voltage and current?

The closest I got to lightning was once in an office, where a bolt hit the earth wire of the building and a wall clock stopped. The loudest thunder I ever heard most probably accompanied by the bang of the short circuit within this clock. The funny thing about it was months later I was in that office again someone asked for the time. Not knowing (it wasn't my office) the clock wasn't repaired I pointed to it. It was mere coincidence it was quite accurately showing the correct time, though the clock still stood still.

It's not always that easy to get out of the water fast: I once was riding a canoe in the middle of a lake (about 2 miles diameter), when a thunderstorm arrived so fast, that I couldn't make it to the shore in time (you need about half an hour for that). So I did, what was probably the worst idea: I raced for the nearest shore, and hid from the rain under a big but short willow tree in the boat near the shore. Fortunately, the lightning didn't strike near me, but I was afraid, it would.

Awesome! but, you explained voltage and current like they were 2 independent entities, when a higher voltage allows more current to flow through a constant resistance, the reason the capacitor does not harm you is because it is a low capacitance, basically rather than in amps, it uses the unit Joules, that formula is 1/2 * C *V^2, or atleast I'm pretty sure, if we where to look at the current of the capacitor it is extremely high ( only limited by the resistance of the conductors ) ( so your 200kv capacitor does have a high voltage high current ) however, the output charge only lasts less than a micro-seconds, so power in wats is Joules/ time. So assuming your capacitor is around .01nF ( I would guess this anyways although it may be a little less, or more, I am actually pretty curious about that, so if you could measure it and let me know I would love that !! :D ) then the power in joules at 200kv is about .2 joules so yeah, that's why you don't get hurt xD btw, love your videos! :D

+Physics Girl Just a correction, when you said that in a car if you touched a metal you would get shocked is not true because your body would be the path of higher resistance, while the rest of the car(made of metal) would be the lowest resistance path to the ground, so your body would have no potential to pass current through.

Another tip for lightning storms. Don't stand near a campfire. The smoke has lots of ions which makes it act like a lightning rod.
Also cows allegedly tend to align themselves facing 90 degrees away from lightning storms because if the current travels along the ground there is less potential difference between their legs than if they are facing towards or away from the lightning. I'm an electrician and I've heard this current vs voltage debate with respect to electrocution go on and on and on and the fact is NEITHER are sufficient indications.  Time and the total power integral are what's important.  That is, how much energy you absorb, and how fast you absorb it.  Your charged bowl apparatus is essentially a capacitor having capacitance in the tens of picofarads.  The shock sustained from discharging it will be of high voltage and high current meaning it actually is quite powerful, which you can see by how bright and loud it was but the duration (and thus the integral energy) is so small that it can't seriously harm you or your ham.  (BTW, your ham spark was weak because having the ham in contact with the bowl creates a site for corona loss to leak your charge away.  It defeats the purpose of using a bowl at all. Try putting your grounded ham man at the end of the stick and drawing the arc to him instead of from.)  If you were to sustain that level of current flow by using a larger capacitor or a 200kV voltage source you could kill a person or maybe even explode one into a fine bloody mist.  It's just a matter of time.

loved that video. I was about 26 years old and a power pole got hit by lightning. It was maybe 30 feel from me. The boom was defining; the flash blinding, and I felt tingling all over my body with burning in the soles of my feet. My girlfriend felt tingling her hands that lasted the rest of the day. It was an experience we will never forget.

If caught out in the open, and you feel a tingle building up, get on your knees, place your palms on your knees and keep your head below your shoulders. That way, the lightning will travel shoulders > hands > knees > earth. It won't be pleasant but you should survive. Advice given to me years ago.

My closest experience with lightning was a lightning bolt striking right out side my room window.

There was a huge boom and my entire room lit up into the brightest blue I've ever seen and my digital piano let out a loud weird hum even when it was switched off. It's probably an EMP and I had to switch on and off my piano for the sound to stop.

You forgot to mention about the exponential increase in resistance of the ground (as distance increases) for electricity.  So if you are standing sideways, near a tree, as the current dissipates into the ground, your leg spread will have less resistance than the ground, so the lightning (following the path of least resistance) will actually come out of the ground, go through your body and back into the ground.  Needless to say doing damage to you on it's path.
